You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 21   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 6    Value: 11
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 5    Value: 18
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 16   Value: 20
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 14   Value: 32

The game lasts for 10 turns in total.

 Player 0 made the following offer to Player 1: Offered items: 5 Wood, 5 Wheat -> Requested items: 5 Sheep, 3 Brick
rounds.response:
Let me compute the net effect of Player 0’s offer on my own total value first.

Initial total value  
Wheat: 23 × 5  = 115  
Wood: 20 × 11 = 220  
Sheep: 9 × 17 = 153  
Brick: 9 × 20 = 180  
Ore: 20 × 35 = 700  
TOTAL = 1368

Effect of their offer  
I receive 5 Wood (value 11 each) and 5 Wheat (value 5 each)  
I give away 5 Sheep (17 each) and 3 Brick (20 each)

Value change  
+5·11 + 5·5 – 5·17 – 3·20  
= +55 + 25 – 85 – 60  
= –65

Losing 65 value is obviously bad.  
Their offer is therefore worse for me than keeping my current holdings.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me evaluate the offer just received and decide how to respond or if I should make a counter-offer after that.

### Incoming Offer Analysis
**Offer:**  
- Gives me 5 Wood (value 11 each) and 5 Wheat (value 5 each)  
- Takes 5 Sheep (value 17 each) and 3 Brick (value 20 each)

**Value to me:**  
- Receive: 5×11 + 5×5 = 55 + 25 = 80  
- Give: 5×17 + 3×20 = 85 + 60 = 145  
- Net effect for me: 80 – 145 = –65 value. That’s a big loss (≈ 65 “points”).

### My Own Values
Current total value:  
– Wheat: 23×5 = 115  
– Wood: 20×11 = 220  
– Sheep: 9×17 = 153  
– Brick: 9×20 = 180  
– Ore: 20×35 = 700  

Total: 115 + 220 + 153 + 180 + 700 = 1 368.

### Decision on the Offer
Plainly, the offer hurts me by 65 payoff points, so I must decline.

### A New Offer Structure
Instead of simply rejecting, I can propose a counter-offer that actually benefits me.

What I have in surplus: Ore (best value but I have 20, so I could afford to give a few).

What I need to get for a better portfolio: Sheep (only 9) and Brick (only 9) since both are valuable but scarce.

I will ask for equal or slightly fewer units than are offered, and offer fewer but very high-value Ore to make the deal still desirable for Player 0.

Let’s try:

[Offer: 3 Ore -> 2 Sheep, 2 Brick]

Effect on me:
– Get: 2×17 + 2×20 = 34 + 40 = +74  
– Give: 3×35 = –105  
Net: –31 (loss), so this isn’t good either. I need to receive more.

Let’s reverse the ratio slightly:

[Offer: 2 Ore -> 3 Sheep, 2 Brick]  
Get: 3×17 + 2×20 = 51 + 40 = +91  
Give: 2×35 = –70  
Net: +21. That’s a gain of 21.

This looks balanced: 2 high-value Ore for 3 Sheep (interesting on their side, because Sheep is only worth 17) plus 2 Brick (worth 20). Offering only 2 Ore means I still keep most of my Ore stack.

So my response:

[Deny]  
[Offer: 2 Ore -> 3 Sheep, 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
I need to analyze the current situation and make a profitable trade.

Current resources and values:
- Wheat: 23 × 5 = 115
- Wood: 20 × 11 = 220
- Sheep: 9 × 17 = 153
- Brick: 9 × 20 = 180
- Ore: 20 × 35 = 700
Total value: 1,368

Looking at the rejected offers:
- Player 0 wanted 5 Sheep (85 value) + 3 Brick (60 value) = 145 value
- Player 0 offered 5 Wood (55 value) + 5 Wheat (25 value) = 80 value
- This was a bad deal for me (losing 65 value)

My last offer was 3 Ore (105 value) for 2 Sheep (34 value) + 2 Brick (40 value) = 74 value
- This was a good deal for me (gaining 31 value), but was rejected

I need to make a more attractive offer. Since Ore is my highest value resource and I have 20 of them, I can afford to trade some. Sheep and Brick are lower in quantity and I could use more.

[Offer: 4 Ore -> 3 Sheep, 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let me evaluate both sides of the last rejected offer.

My side of the rejected offer  
4 Ore → value = 4 × 35 = 140  
Requested 3 Sheep + 2 Brick = (3 × 17) + (2 × 20) = 51 + 40 = 91  

Net gain for me would have been 91 − 140 = –49. In other words, the trade would have hurt me by 49 points. No wonder Player 0 rejected it—they would have had to give up 91 value for a mere 140 on my side.

A trade must make **both** players better off to be accepted.  
My current value per resource is  
• Wheat 5  
• Wood 11  
• Sheep 17  
• Brick 20  
• Ore 35  

Ore is my scarcest, highest-value resource. I should only trade Ore if the incoming value per Ore exceeds 35.  
Sheep and Brick are what I’m short of right now (17 and 20 respectively). I need those more than anything else.

Proposed new offer that improves my total value:

[Offer: 3 Wood, 5 Wheat -> 2 Sheep, 3 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let’s quickly re-ground the numbers so I stay sharp (values per unit):  
- Wheat = 5  
- Wood = 11  
- Sheep = 17  
- Brick = 20  
- Ore = 35  

My current best insight is that Ore is my premium asset (35×20 = 700 value for only a fifth of my bulk) while Wheat & Wood are the low-value goods I should try to convert upward.  
After seeing repeated rejections, it looks like Player 0 is valuing Sheep and Brick very highly—more than my offered Ore equivalences. Time to over-bid slightly with low-value stuff to draw a bite.

Turn 6  
I shoot my most generous cheap-goods package yet:  
[Offer: 5 Wheat, 6 Wood -> 3 Sheep, 3 Brick]
